heading: 1.4.1 System Usability Scale
text: System Usability Scale (SUS) used [10] widely used adopted usability questionnaire. popular due unbiased agnostic properties, non proprietary, quick scale 10 questions.think like use system frequently.found system unnecessarily complex.thought system easy use.think need support technical person able use system.found various functions system well integrated.thought much inconsistency system.imagine people learn use system quickly.found system cumbersome use.felt confident using system.needed learn lot things get going system.SUS developed scoring system, following performed: odd numbered questions, subtract 1 score. even numbered questions, subtract value 5. Add numbers find total score, multiply 2.5. result score 100 can compared determined average score 68. , 80.3 higher excellent, 51 suggests significant usability problems.

heading: 1.4.2 Computer Self-Efficacy Scale Tool
text: 10 question CSEST based 32-item questionnaire Murphy, Coover, Owen (1989). Participants provided facilitator stating ’Imagine found new technology product previously used. believe product make life better. doesn’t matter specifically technology product , intended make life easier never used . use new technology…one around tell goIf never used product like beforeIf product manuals referenceIf seen someone else using trying myselfIf call someone help got stuckIf someone else helped get startedIf lot time complete job product providedIf just built-help facility assistanceIf someone showed firstIf used similar products one job

heading: 1.4.3 Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology
1.4.4 Technology Acceptance Model (TAM)
text:
Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) [1] specifically developed primary aim identifying determinants involved computer acceptance general; secondly, examine variety information technology usage behaviours; thirdly, provide parsimonious theoretical explanatory model. TAM suggests attitude direct predictor intention use technology, turn predict actual usage technology. modification nine sub-scales questionnaire consists applying items context chatbots. items, except measuring attitudes, utilize seven-point Likert scale ranging “strongly agree” “strongly disagree” middle neutral point [2].nine sub-scales questionnaire:• Ease use chatbots
• Perceived usefulness chatbots
• Intention use.
• Attitude toward usage chatbots.
• Perception personal efficacy use chatbot resource.
• Perception external control toward chatbots.
• Anxiety toward chatbot use.
• Intrinsic motivation use chatbot resources.
• Perceived costs chatbots.

heading: 1.4.5 Qualitative Measure- Focus Group Discussions
text: Focus groups pervasive means market research provides credible acceptance evaluators regarding penetration product service target demographic. Focus groups form qualitative research consisting interviews structured discussions, group people asked perceptions, opinions, beliefs, attitudes towards product, service, concept, advertisement, idea, packaging. Questions asked interactive group setting participants free talk group members. process, researcher either takes notes records vital points getting group. Researchers select members focus group carefully effective authoritative responses. Relevant stakeholders, , can use information collected focus groups receive insights specific product, issue, topic focus [7].series short focus group sessions identified feasibility CEPEH resources formal curricular integration. sessions, spanning 1-1.5 hours consisting 5-7 persons explored axes curricular integration accessibility classroom, use case scenarios, technology requirements curricular integration etc. axes formalized research team, evaluation site, consider curricular details institution.

heading: 4.1 CEPEH Training Event 2
text:
Pre-Training Event survey May 9th-13th 2022 Thessaloniki, GreeceTwenty-six participants attended Training Event, along approximately 10 staff members. 21 undergraduate students 5 postgraduate students, completed survey total 26 responses. 86% participants stated similar event like training event CEPEH facilitated. 90% students found event schedule organised, 70% agreed planned sessions relevant interest remaining 30% enough experience understand context determine interested training event. 95% students agreeing strongly agreeing training event location great, remaining person leave additional comments.Table 1 suggested attendees minimal intention share ideas due lack previous experience attending events, due lack knowledge area. However, interested listening groups hearing contextual cases healthcare.77% participants stated novices experience chatbots healthcare attending learn . remaining 23% (7 students) stated competent limited experience chatbots healthcare.One day several events regarding cybersecurity healthcare. asked events, 83% stated neutral disagreed felt confident cybersecurity knowledge healthcare. addition, 80% stated neutral disagreed felt strong cybersecurity safety healthcare. Table 2 shows main pre post results suggesting positive experience 75% attendees measures.90% (23) students heard event lecturer professor, CEPEH newsletter (2), 1 person informed anatomy tutoring system Karolinska Institute. Additionally, 60% suggested training event somebody else course started.six individuals stated neutral disagree asked issues registration finding information event. may due dependent emails receive information, instead dedicated website information available anytime.face--face, participants asked sufficient Covid-19 precautions place facility, 94% agreed sufficient precautions, two individuals stated give information additional input box provided.
summary, participants undergraduate students novice experience, happy training event location, felt sessions relevant , shared event colleagues. values co-creation, chatbots healthcare, taking patient history bestowed students engaging well-received manner. Notably, highest ratings staff friendliness key engagement consistent interaction throughout intense long 5-day duration. sessions recorded online recordings may viewed higher numbers subsequent weeks.usual way include citations R Markdown document put references plain text file extension .bib, BibTex format.3

code:
@article{Shea2014,
  author =        {Shea, Nicholas and Boldt, Annika},
  journal =       {Trends in Cognitive Sciences},
  pages =         {186--193},
  title =         {{Supra-personal cognitive control}},
  volume =        {18},
  year =          {2014},
  doi =           {10.1016/j.tics.2014.01.006},
}

heading: 4.1.1 Appearance of citations and references section (pandoc)
text:
default, oxforddown lets Pandoc handle citations inserted text references section.
can change appearance citations references specifying CSL (Citation Style Language) file csl metadata field index.Rmd.
default, oxforddown Americal Psychological Association (7th Edition), author-year format.style, number variations citation syntax useful know:Put author names outside parenthesis
: @Shea2014 says blah.
Becomes: Shea et al. (2014) says blah.
: @Shea2014 says blah.Becomes: Shea et al. (2014) says blah.Include citation-year (parenthesis)
: Shea et al. says blah [-@Shea2014]
Becomes: Shea et al. says blah (2014)
: Shea et al. says blah [-@Shea2014]Becomes: Shea et al. says blah (2014)Add text page chapter references citation
: [see @Shea2014, pp. 33-35; also @Wu2016, ch. 1]
Becomes: Blah blah (see Shea et al., 2014, pp. 33–35; also Wu, 2016, ch. 1).
: [see @Shea2014, pp. 33-35; also @Wu2016, ch. 1]Becomes: Blah blah (see Shea et al., 2014, pp. 33–35; also Wu, 2016, ch. 1).want numerical citation style instead, try csl: bibliography/transactions--computer-human-interaction.csl just browse Zotero Style Repository look one like.
convenience, can set line spacing space bibliographic entries reference section directly YAML header index.Rmd.prefer use biblatex natbib handle references, see chapter.

heading: 4.1.2 Insert references easily with RStudio’s Visual Editor
text:
easy way insert citations, use RStudio’s Visual Editor.
Make sure latest version RStudio – visual editor originally really buggy, especially relation references, per v2022.02.0, ’s great!

heading: 4.2 Cross-referencing
text: can make cross-references sections within document, well figures (images plots) tables.general cross-referencing syntax \@ref(label)

heading: 4.2.1 Section references
text: Headers automatically assigned reference label, text lower caps separated dashes. example, # header automatically given label -header. # header can referenced \@ref(-section)Remember wrote section ???can also use hyperlink syntax add # label, though guaranteed work properly HTML output:write Remember wrote [previous section](#citations)?becomes Remember wrote previous section?

text:
good idea create custom labels sections. automatically assigned labels change change titles sections - avoid , can create labels leave untouched change section titles.create custom labels adding {#label} header, e.g. # section {#-label}.
See chapter title example. section 3.

refer tables use syntax \@ref(tab:label)refer table \@ref(tab:cars-table2).

heading: 4.2.4 Including page numbers
text:
Finally, PDF output might also want include page number reference, ’s easy find physical printed output.
LaTeX command , looks like : \pageref{fig/tab:label} (note: curly braces, parentheses)output PDF, can use raw LaTeX directly .Rmd files. wanted include page cars plot write:: Figure \@ref(fig:cars-plot) page \pageref(fig:cars-plot)Becomes: Figure 2.4 page

heading: 4.2.4.1 Include page numbers only in PDF output
text: problem LaTeX commands don’t display HTML output, gitbook output ’d see simply “Figure 2.4 page”.One way get around use inline R code insert text, use ifelse statement check output format insert appropriate text.: `r ifelse(knitr::is_latex_output(), "Figure \\@ref(fig:cars-plot) page \\pageref{fig:cars-plot}", "")`Inserts (check PDF gitbook):Note need escape backslash another backslash get correct output.

heading: 4.3 Collaborative writing
text:
Best practices collaboration change tracking using R Markdown still open question.
blog post One year dissertate Lucy D’Agostino, highly recommend, author notes knits .Rmd files word document, uses googledrive R package send Google Drive comments / revisions co-authors, incorporates Google Drive suggestions hand .Rmd source files.
bit clunky, ongoing discussions among R Markdown developers best way handle collaborative writing (see issue #1463 GitHub, CriticMarkup among suggestions).now, open question community R Markdown users.
often knit format can easily imported Google Docs comments, go suggested revisions manually incorporate back .Rmd source files.
articles, sometimes upload near-final draft Overleaf, collaboratively make final edits LaTeX file .
suspect great solution developed --distant future, probably RStudio team.

heading: 5.1.1 Making your table pretty

use kable create tables, almost certainly want set option booktabs = TRUE.
makes table look million times better:Compare default style, looks terrible:

might find table expands margins page, like tables .
Fix kable_styling function kableExtra package:scales table fit page width.

kable_styling function kableExtra:Unfortunately, use scale_down option longtable.
longtable wide, can either manually adjust font size, show table landscape layout.
adjust font size, use kableExtra’s font_size option:put table landscape mode, use kableExtra’s landscape function:

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.4 Unnumbered chapters
text: make chapters unnumbered (normally relevant Introduction /Conclusion), follow chapter header {-}, e.g. # Introduction {-}., must also follow heading two latex commands:Otherwise chapter’s mini table contents running header show previous chapter.

\adjustmtc
\markboth{The Name of Your Unnumbered Chapter}{}

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.9 Including another paper in your thesis - embed a PDF document
text:
may want embed existing PDF documents thesis, example department allows ‘portfolio’ style thesis need include existing typeset publication chapter.gitbook output, can simply use knitr::include_graphics include scrollable (downloadable) PDF.
probably want set chunk options .width='100%' .height='1000px':LaTeX output, however, approach can cause odd behaviour.
Therefore, build thesis PDF, split PDF alphanumerically sorted sequence single-page PDF files (can automatically package pdftools). can use appropriate LaTeX command insert , shown (brevity, oxforddown PDF sample content ’re including two pages).
Note chunk option results='asis' must set.
may also want remove margins PDF files, can Adobe Acrobat (paid version) likely software.
code:
# install.packages(pdftools)
# split PDF into pages stored in figures/sample-content/pdf_embed_example/split/
# pdftools::pdf_split("figures/sample-content/pdf_embed_example/Lyngs2020_FB.pdf",
#        output = "figures/sample-content/pdf_embed_example/split/")

# grab the pages
pages <- list.files("figures/sample-content/pdf_embed_example/split", full.names = TRUE)

# set how wide you want the inserted PDFs to be: 
# 1.0 is 100 per cent of the oxforddown PDF page width;
# you may want to make it a bit bigger
pdf_width <- 1.2

# for each PDF page, insert it nicely and
# end with a page break
cat(stringr::str_c("\\newpage \\begin{center} \\makebox[\\linewidth][c]{\\includegraphics[width=", pdf_width, "\\linewidth]{", pages, "}} \\end{center}"))

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.10 Including another paper in your thesis - R Markdown child document
text:
Sometimes want include another paper currently writing chapter thesis.
6.9, described simplest way : include paper pdf.
However, cases instead want include R Markdown source paper, compiled within thesis.
little bit tricky, need keep careful track file paths, possible including paper child document.
four main steps:Include paper child documentMake file paths compatible knitting article , well ’s include thesisMake header levels correctMake figure widths correct

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.10.1 An example paper in another folder
text:
Take simple example (files GitHub repository):chart suggests, another folder, paper_to_include/ living containing folder thesis folder.
paper_to_include folder, file my_paper.Rmd write paper.
my_paper.Rmd, read CSV file found subfolder data/cats.csv, also image subfolder figures/cat.jpg.
code:
|--paper_to_include
|  |--my_paper.Rmd
|  |--data
|  |  |--cat_salt.csv
|  |--figures
|  |  |--cat.jpg
|
|--thesis

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.10.2 Step 1: Include paper as a child document
text:
thesis folder, create Rmd file chapter want include another paper.
Add one code chunks include R Markdown files paper child documents:

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.10.3 Step 2: Make file paths compatible
text:
Use parameters adjust file path images based values set YAML header R Markdown file.
my_paper.Rmd, create parameter called other_path set empty string:my_paper.Rmd, put start filepath read data include images:Finally, thesis folder’s index.Rmd file, also create parameter other_path.
, set paper_to_include/ folder relative thesis folder:
code:
---
title: "A fabulous article in a different folder"
params:
  other_path: ""
---
library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)

cat_data <- read_csv(str_c(params$other_path, "data/cats.csv"))
include_graphics(str_c(params$other_path, "figures/cat.jpg"))params:
  other_path: "../paper_to_include/"

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.10.3.1 Note on HTML output
text: Note want host HTML version thesis online, need include graphics content host online - internet obviously won’t able see filepaths just referring stuff another folder computer!

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.10.4 Step 3: Make sure header levels are correct
text:
Unless paper want include also written book, header levels probably going .
, level 1 headers (# header) use main sections paper turns chaper titles included thesis.avoid , first increment heading levels one paper_to_include/my_paper.Rmd (# header -> ## header).
paper_to_include/ create lua filter decrements header levels one: Create text file, save reduce_header_level.lua, give content .YAML header paper_to_include/my_paper.Rmd, use filter:Now, header levels correct knit paper included thesis.NOTE: might need use lua filter shift heading - seems simply use pandoc_args: ["--shift-heading-level-=-1"] (see https://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#reader-options)
code:
function Header(el)
  if (el.level <= 1) then
    error("I don't know how to decrease the level of h1")
  end
  el.level = el.level - 1
  return el
end---
title: "A fabulous article in a different folder"
params:
  other_path: ""
output:
  pdf_document: 
    pandoc_args: ["--lua-filter=reduce_header_level.lua"]
---

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.10.5 Step 4. Make sure figure widths are correct
text:
might figure widths knitting paper , including thesis, need different.
can use parameters set figure widths.Imagine want figure width 80% page width knitting paper , 100% thesis.
paper_to_include/my_paper.Rmd, first add parameter call out_width set string “80%”:, make sure use parameter set output width include figures paper_to_include/my_paper.Rmd:Finally, create parameter out_width thesis’ index.Rmd file:Now, output width figure 80% knitting paper , 100% knitting child document thesis.
code:
---
title: "A fabulous article in a different folder"
params:
  other_path: ""
  out_width: "80%"
output:
  pdf_document: 
    pandoc_args: ["--lua-filter=reduce_header_level.lua"]
---```{r, out.width=params$out_width, fig.cap="A very funny cat"}
include_graphics(str_c(params$other_path, "figures/cat.jpg"))
```params:
  other_path: "../paper_to_include/"
  out_width: "80%"

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.11 Customizing citations and referencing

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.11.1 Using a .csl file with pandoc
text: See section 4.1.1.drawbacks letting pandoc handle citations () support chapter bibliographies, (ii) ’re LaTeX veteran, might comfortable biblatex natbib.

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.11.2 Using biblatex
text: use biblatex handle citations, first uncomment index.Rmd, YAML header:tell R Markdown use biblatex inserting citations, setting citation_package: biblatex:customise appearance citations, change bib-latex-options. example, get numerical citations, references order appearance text, set
code:
use-biblatex: true
bib-latex-options: "style=authoryear, sorting=nyt, backend=biber, maxcitenames=2, useprefix, doi=true, isbn=false, uniquename=false"output:
  bookdown::pdf_book:
    citation_package: biblatexbib-latex-options: "style=numeric-comp, sorting=none, backend=biber, maxcitenames=2, useprefix, doi=true, isbn=false, uniquename=false"

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.11.2.1 Adding chapter bibliographies
text: like chapter bibliographies, first add “refsection=chapter” biblatex options, example like :Second, set parameter insertHeadingInPDF: false index.Rmd, suppress inclusion ‘References’ heading end thesis.Finally insert line end chapter, print bibliographies :
code:
bib-latex-options: "refsection=chapter, style=authoryear, sorting=nyt, backend=biber, maxcitenames=2, useprefix, doi=true, isbn=false, uniquename=false"params:
  insertHeadingInPDF: false\printbibliography[segment=\therefsection,heading=subbibliography]

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.11.3 Using natbib
text: use natbib handle citations, first uncomment index.Rmd, YAML header:tell R Markdown use natbib inserting citations, setting citation_package: natbib:customise appearance citations, change .bst file point natbib-bibliography-style.
code:
use-natbib: true
natbib-citation-style: authoryear #for science, you might want numbers,square
natbib-bibliography-style: templates/ACM-Reference-Format.bst #e.g. "plainnat", unsrtnat, or path to a .bst fileoutput:
  bookdown::pdf_book:
    citation_package: natbib

heading: More info
text:
’s random info:
first paragraph chapter title section head shouldn’t indented, indents tell reader ’re starting new paragraph.
Since ’s obvious chapter section title, proper typesetting doesn’t add indent .paragraph, contrast, indented first one ‘info’ heading.
hail LaTeX. (’re reading HTML version, won’t see indentation - look PDF version understand earth section babbling ).
